item.title: The Untold Story of Silk Road, Part 1
item.description:
The Untold Story of Silk Road, Part 1

How a 29-year-old idealist built a global drug bazaar and became a murderous kingpin.

item.title: Karl Ove Knausgård: In America, an Alcoholic-In Scandinavia, Just a Genius
item.description:
Karl Ove Knausgård: In America, an Alcoholic-In Scandinavia, Just a Genius

Karl Ove Knausgård, a Norwegian now domiciled with his wife and four kids in Sweden, is perhaps the world's most revered living writer. Only, if he were American, the principal thing he and everyone else would say about him is that he is an alcoholic.

item.title: Kennett: AFL should consider scrapping illicit drugs policy
item.description:
Kennett: AFL should consider scrapping illicit drugs policy

Jeff Kennett: "this should not be a matter for the players". Photo: Darrian Traynor Former premier and Hawthorn president Jeff Kennett has suggested the AFL scrap the illicit drugs policy because the system is "half pregnant".

item.title: US Agents Watch as 'Narco Sub' Carrying $194 Million Worth of Cocaine Sinks After Bust | VICE News
item.description:
US Agents Watch as 'Narco Sub' Carrying $194 Million Worth of Cocaine Sinks After Bust | VICE News

US authorities nearly caught a white whale this week: A semi-submersible "narco sub" carrying around 5.5 tons cocaine worth nearly $194 million. But before the Americans could haul their catch ashore, the boat sank to the bottom of the ocean with all of its illicit cargo still aboard.

item.title: LSD Could Help Fight Depression By Inhibiting "Mental Time Travel"
item.description:
LSD Could Help Fight Depression By Inhibiting "Mental Time Travel"

Taking lysergic acid diethylamide - better known as LSD - could help people who suffer from depression to overcome their condition by preventing them from "ruminating" on past experiences. Several studies have shown that low mood is often associated with a tendency to dwell on one's own history, yet new research indicates that LSD may inhibit the brain network that mediates this type of "mental time travel."

item.title: 5 Policies That Prove The War On Drugs Targeted Black People
item.description:
5 Policies That Prove The War On Drugs Targeted Black People

It came as no surprise to some African-Americans this week when news broke that a former aide to President Richard M. Nixon developed anti-drug policies that targeted Black people. A new article from Harper's magazine features a 1994 interview with Nixon's formeradvisor John D.

item.title: This Former Gangster Is the Most Terrifying Anti-Drug Speaker of All Time | VICE | United States
item.description:
This Former Gangster Is the Most Terrifying Anti-Drug Speaker of All Time | VICE | United States

Paul Hannaford Last week I spoke to four former London gang members to see if their experiences tallied with the media depiction of the city's gang situation. They were all interesting characters, but one guy in particular struck me as having a story to tell that went way beyond his involvement in gangs.

item.title: Brazil seizes abortion drugs sent to women living in fear of Zika
item.description:
Brazil seizes abortion drugs sent to women living in fear of Zika

The messages from the expectant mothers in Brazil resonate with desperation."I'm thinking of doing the worst," one woman wrote when her order for abortion medication failed to arrive. "I really need help. I can no longer eat, and I cry all the time."The messages were sent to an international advocacy...

item.title: Know Before You Toke: How Not to End Up in the ER on Your Excellent Pot Tourism Adventure
item.description:
Know Before You Toke: How Not to End Up in the ER on Your Excellent Pot Tourism Adventure

After relocating to Denver last month, I soon noticed a flurry of articles in local and national media suggesting that marijuana is increasingly driving Colorado visitors to hospitals. Other than feeling vaguely relieved to no longer count myself among the vacationers here, I wasn't sure what to make of this information.

item.title: Microsoft Apologizes for Creating a Teenage, Racist, Homophobic Chatbot
item.description:
Microsoft Apologizes for Creating a Teenage, Racist, Homophobic Chatbot

In a blog post posted Friday, Microsoft executive Peter Lee apologized for the disturbing behavior of its chatbot, Tay. Originally crafted in order to "experiment with and conduct research on conversational understanding," Tay's chats quickly took a darker turn.
